docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Albania threw the General Assembly into turmoil today with a demand that the Assembly take an immediate roll-call vote whether to continue the no-vote procedure it has followed for two and a half months.
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Albania threw the General Assembly into turmoil today with a demand that the Assembly take an immediate roll-call vote whether to continue the no-vote procedure it has followed for two and a half months.
docs.abstract: Quaison-Sackey forced to recess Assembly 2 days to avoid showdown over USSR arrears from persistent demand by Albanian Amb Budo for immediate roll-call vote whether to continue no-vote procedure; agreement had been reached on issues to be disposed of without vote before long recess; Stevenson, others see Communist China behind Albanian move

headline.main: ALBANIAN UPSETS U.N. BY VOTE CALL; Uproar and Two-Day Recess Follow Stubborn Demand by an Ally of Peking ALBANIAN UPSETS U.N. BY VOTE CALL

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 -- Walt W. Rostow, chairman of the State Department's Policy Planning Council, ended a four-day visit today convinced that Argentina would make "positive progress" toward bringing inflation under control.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 -- Walt W. Rostow, chairman of the State Department's Policy Planning Council, ended a four-day visit today convinced that Argentina would make "positive progress" toward bringing inflation under control.
docs.abstract: US official W W Rostow, after 4-day talks, predicts Govt progress against inflation; Argentine fears seen eased by pledges that US backs Alliance aid; Export-Import Bank grants 2 loans; Martin concern for pol effect of aid delays linked

headline.main: Peter D. Howard Diesin Peru; Leader of Moral Re-Armament; Head of Movement Seeking a New Social Order Was on Tour of South America

docs.snippet: BOGOTA -- Although there are exceptions, most South Americans have taken their splendid tourist resources for granted and have done relatively little to exploit them. Where something has been done -- a hotel built, a paved road laid out -- it was...
docs.lead_paragraph: BOGOTA -- Although there are exceptions, most South Americans have taken their splendid tourist resources for granted and have done relatively little to exploit them. Where something has been done -- a hotel built, a paved road laid out -- it was done largely for domestic travelers, and the question of attracting foreign visitors was barely considered.

headline.main: THE SOUTH AMERICAN WAY; Many Holiday Spots Are Strictly for Native Population, But the Foreign Traveler Will Find Plenty to Do
